title: Rethinking dyslexia
intro: Dyslexia is a condition which makes it difficult for people to read, write and spell. While this may make certain school subjects a struggle, many dyslexic people enjoy enormous success in their working life, across many different industries. Can the ability to process information differently actually be an advantage? And why do dyslexics make excellent spies? Phil and Pippa discuss this and teach you some new vocabulary.
this_week_question: a) Stephen Hawking b) Albert Einstein c) Marie Curie
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: essential skill which is useful or important in everyone’s life, such as reading, cooking, problem-solving or time management superpower ability or capacity to do something that other people cannot do spy person who secretly collects information about another country’s government or organisations read people ability to understand people’s real intentions through their behaviour and body language value (something) consider something important reach for the stars (idiom) have high or ambitious aims; try to achieve something difficult even if it seems impossible

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Phil.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: And I'm Pippa. Are you a big reader, Phil?

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Sometimes yes, sometimes no. Sometimes I go a while without reading anything. What about you?

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Well, I really love to read. I read on the train to work all the time.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Ah, well, that is a great way to get some reading in, I guess.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Yes and reading, of course, is a life skill – an essential skill which is useful or important in everyone's life. But reading can be a struggle for people with dyslexia – a learning difficulty making it hard for people to read, write or spell.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: It's thought that around one in ten people in the UK are dyslexic, and many dyslexic children struggle at school, where the focus is on reading and writing. But in this episode, we'll be hearing how dyslexics have other skills which allow them to excel in the workplace. As usual, we'll be learning some useful new words and phrases, and remember, you'll find all the vocabulary for this episode on our website, bbclearningenglish.com.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: But first, I have a question for you, Phil. Studies have shown that people with dyslexia have enhanced abilities in certain areas and can excel in creative thinking, problem solving and inventiveness. So, which famous scientist was dyslexic? Was it: a)    Stephen Hawking, b)    Albert Einstein, or c)    Marie Curie?

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Oh, I think... I think it's b) – I think it's Albert Einstein.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out the answer at the end of the programme. Now, the British charity Made By Dyslexia shares online learning tools and works with schools and teachers to raise awareness about the condition. The charity recently collaborated with British celebrities who have dyslexia for this promotional video:

transcript.author: Orlando Bloom
transcript.text: If you're dyslexic, it's kind of your superpower . It's, like, the way that you think.

transcript.author: Richard Branson
transcript.text: Our brains – they're wired to, I think, process information differently.

transcript.author: Keira Knightley
transcript.text: The way I see the world might be different from somebody else, but that's valid. In fact, it's vital.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: You might recognise some of those voices, including actors Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley and businessman Richard Branson. The message is that, far from being a disability, dyslexia is their superpower – the ability to do something other people can't.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Made By Dyslexia was founded by social entrepreneur Kate Griggs, and Kate co-authored a report showing that empowering dyslexic workers could boost the global economy by billions. BBC World Service programme People Fixing the World met Kate at the report's London launch event, where she explained why being dyslexic can actually give advantages in life, including some exciting job prospects.

transcript.author: Kate Griggs
transcript.text: If you think about what you have to do as a spy , you have to be reading people really quickly, spotting complex patterns and solving problems really quickly, so you can see whether there's a terror threat. It's natural that dyslexics are brilliant spies .

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Kate thinks dyslexics make good spies – people who secretly collect information about another country's government or organisations. Why? Because they're good at reading people . To read people means to be able to understand someone's true intentions through their body language and behaviour, rather than their words.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Also present at the London charity event was space scientist and dyslexic herself, Dr Maggie Aderin-Pocock. Here, Maggie tells BBC World Service's People Fixing the World how being dyslexic contributes different skills and ideas to her project teams:

transcript.author: Dr Maggie Aderin-Pocock
transcript.text: Well, I think it's recognising people's skills and differences. It's about teamwork and collaboration. We do it in science and that's when we reach for the stars , but to do that, we need to know our skills and value all the skills.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Maggie thinks that everyone's skills should be valued – or considered important. Dyslexics may struggle to read or spell, but their skills in problem-solving and communication, for example, can be essential for scientific success.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: By valuing everyone's contribution, business and science teams can reach for the stars – an idiom meaning to be ambitious and try to achieve something difficult, even if it seems impossible.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: And talking of reaching for the stars , Pippa, I think it's time you revealed the answer to your question about successful scientists.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Yes, I asked you which famous scientist was dyslexic. Was it a) Stephen Hawking, b) Albert Einstein, or c) Marie Curie? And you were right, Phil. It was Albert Einstein. OK. Let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with life skill – an essential skill, such as reading or problem-solving, which is useful in everyone's life.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: A superpower is the ability to do something that other people can't.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: A spy is someone who secretly collects information about other countries' governments or organisations.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: If you're good at reading people , you can understand people's real intentions through how they act and behave, instead of what they say.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: If you value something or someone, you consider them to be important.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: And finally, the idiom to reach for the stars means to have high or ambitious aims and try to achieve something difficult, even if it seems impossible.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Once again, our six minutes are up, but remember, you can find many more trending topics, plus a quiz and worksheet for this episode, on our website, bbclearningenglish.com. Hope to see you there soon, but for now, it's goodbye!
